Data Name: Biomass as Feedstock for a Bioenergy and Bioproducts Industry:  The Technical Feasibility of a Billion-Ton Annual Supply
Abstract/Comments/Notes: This report determines whether the land resources are capable of producing a sustainable supply of biomass sufficient to displace 30% or more of the country's present petroleum consumption by examining the potential resource availability of agricultural and forest lands for biomass energy production.

Data Name: Biomass Feedstock Availability in the United States:  1999 State Level Analysis
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Estimates of biomass quantities and prices for each state in the continental U.S., with links to a spreadsheet containing estimates of biomass quantities potentially available in five categories: mill wastes, urban wastes, forest residues, agricultural residues and energy crops. Availabilities are sorted by anticipated delivered price. Superseded by an updated study by Marie Walsh and the University of Tennessee in 2006.

Data Name: National Biomass Resource Assessment/ A Geographic Perspective on the Current Biomass Resource Availability in the United States
Abstract/Comments/Notes: This analysis illustrates the biomass resources available in the United States by county. Biomass feedstock data are analyzed both statistically and graphically using GIS. The following feedstock categories are evaluated: crop residues, forest residues, primary and secondary mill residues, urban wood waste, and methane emissions from manure management, landfills, and domestic wastewater treatment. The resource potential is based on county level statistics gathered from U.S. Department of Agriculture, U.S. Forest Service, EPA and other organizations.

Data Name: Biomass from Crop Residues: Cost and Supply Estimates.
Source: Office of Energy Policy and New Uses
Abstract/Comments/Notes: The analysis estimated the supply of harvested crop residues as a feed stock for energy products. The estimates account for economic and environmental factors governing residue supply. The supply results span major agricultural crops in four distinct cropping regions of the United States, taking into account local variation in cost-determining factors such as residue yield, geographic density ofresidues, and competition for livestock feed use.

Data Name: Biomass Residue Supply Curves for the United States
Abstract/Comments/Notes: The project estimated the availability of biomass resources and built supply curves for each state. It focused on woody biomass resources such as forestry, mills, and urban residues.

This study collected and analyzed data on urban wood waste resources in 30 randomly selected metropolitan areas in the United States. The metropolitan areas ranged in size from Bismarck, North Dakota (83,831) to Washington, DC (3,923,574).Three major categories of urban wood wastes were considered in this study: MSW wood, industrial wood, and Construction/Demolition debris.

This study describes the distribution, quantity, availability, competing uses, and current market value of select lignocellulosic feedstock in the United States. It provides feedstock data at a state  level.

Data Name: Secondary Mill Residues and Urban Wood WasteQuantities in the United States
Source: Jeffrey E. Fehrs, P.E.Williston, Vermont
Abstract/Comments/Notes: This study focuses on secondary mill residues and urban wood wastes, and estimates quantities and prices based on seven national wood waste assessments completed by others.

The book represents an assembly and display of statistics and information that characterize the biomass industry, from the production of biomass feedstocks to their end use. It inlcudes the following feedstocks: grains and oilseed crops, some crop residues, forest residues, secondary mill residues and urban wood waste (construction and demolition wood debris, municipal solid wastes, and landfill gases).

Data Name: U.S. Cellulose Biomass Feedstock Supplies and Distribution
Source: Marie Walsh & University of Tennessee's POLYSYS Team
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Agricultural residues (corn and wheat assuming current mix of tillage practices), forestry, mill, urban wood wastes and potential bioenergy crops (primarily switchgrass).  Sensitivity cases for agricultural residues were analyzed, i.e., different tillage practices. Interim updated results are posted on http://bioweb.sungrant.org subsequent to the April 2006 release of the report. Corn stover removal is constrained by the need to maintain soil characteristics.

Data Name: Liquid Transportation Fuels from Coal and Biomass: Technological Status, Costs, and Environmental Impacts
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Agricultural residues, dedicated energy crops, woody biomass, animal manure, and municipal solid waste. The panel presented a scenario in which 548 million dry tons of lignocellulosic feedstock could be harvested or produced sustainably in 2020. The supply of biomass could exceed the panel‰Ûªs estimate if croplands are used more efficiently or if genetic improvement of dedicated fuel crops exceeds the panel‰Ûªs estimate. In contrast, the panel‰Ûªs estimate could be lower if producers decide not to harvest agricultural residues or not to grow dedicated fuel crops on their CRP land.

Data Name: WGA CDEAC Biomass Task Force Report, Supply Addendum
Spatial Coverage: WA, OR, ID, MT, WY, CO, NM, AZ, UT, NV, CA, TX, ND, SD, NE, KS, AK and HI
Units: Varies by type: bone dry tons/yr; as-is tons; or millions of gallons/day
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Estimates of current and future biomass feedstocks by state for WGA member states.  Bone dry tons/yr is used for agriculture, forestry, and municipal wastes; as-is tons is used for landfill waste in place; and millions of gallons/day for wastewater treatment plant influent.  Includes supply curves of relative resource cost.

Data Name: Securing a Place for Biomass in theNortheast United States:A Review of Renewable Energy andRelated Policies
Source: CONEG Policy Research Center, Inc.Northeast Regional Biomass Program
Spatial Coverage: CT, DE, ME, MD, MA, NH, NJ, NY, PA, RI, VT
Abstract/Comments/Notes: A survey of biomass resources, power potential, and policies in the 11 states encompassing the Northeast Regional Biomass Program (NRBP): CT, DE, ME, MD, MA, NH, NJ, NY, PA, RI, VT.

Data Name: Assessment of Biomass Resources and Power Generation Potential in California
Abstract/Comments/Notes: California's gross and potential technically available biomass resources were quantified and compiled into statewide and county level inventories.

Data Name: Potential for Biomass Energy Development in South Carolina
Source: U.S. Department of Agriculture Forest Service and South Carolina SC Forestry Commission
Abstract/Comments/Notes: This report quantifies the amount of forestry and agricultural biomass that is available for energy production on a sustainable basis in South Carolina. It also determines the economics of utilizing the biomass that is available; conducts a cost/benefit analysis taking into account the direct and indirect benefits to the state, and determine the amount of subsidy that could be justified to promote biomass energy; identifies other factors that should be considered before the State commits to develop a biomass energy program.

Data Name: Biomass and Bioenergy Resource Assessment for the State of Hawaii
Source: State of Hawaii Department of Business, Economic Development and Tourism
Abstract/Comments/Notes: An assessment of current and potential biomass and bioenergy resources for the State of Hawaii. It includes the following feedstock: animal wastes, forest products residues, agricultural residues, and urban wastes

Data Name: Biomass Wood Resource Assessment on aCounty-by-County Basis for the State of Georgia
Source: Georgia Forestry Commission and Southern States Energy Board
Abstract/Comments/Notes: A biomass wood resource assessment on a county level basis for the State of Georgia: forest, primary mill, urban wood, pecan shells, paper mill sludge, and black liquor. It also analyzes the CRP Program potential.

Data Name: Biomass Inventory and BioenergyAssessmentAn Evaluation of Organic Material Resourcesfor Bioenergy Production in Washington State
Source: Washington State University and Washington State Department of Ecology
Abstract/Comments/Notes: This project geographically identified, categorized, and mapped 45 potential sources in Washington at a county level. The categories included field residues, animal manures, forestry residues, food packing/processing waste, and municipal wastes. The biomass inventory was then converted to potential energy production using anaerobic digestion and simple combustion as representative conversion technologies.

Data Name: Assessing Ohio‰Ûªs Biomass Resources for Energy Potential Using GIS
Abstract/Comments/Notes: This study funded by Ohio DOD involves a geo-referenced inventory by county of Ohio biomass resources for energy. It includes forest and crop residues, livestock manure, municipal solid waste and food processing waste. This is an update and expansion of an earlier (1982) inventory of biomass by Hitzhusen et al.

Data Name: Biomass Resource Assessment and UtilizationOptions for Three Counties in Eastern Oregon
Source: McNeil Technologies for Oregon Department of Energy
Spatial Scale or Resolution: Three counties in Eastern Oregon - Baker, Union and Wallowa
Abstract/Comments/Notes: The assessment focused on the use of biomass for electric power generation or conversion to ethanol fuel in Baker, Union and Wallowa Counties. The objectives were to identify how much biomass is generated in the region; how much is available, where it is located, its physical and chemical characteristics and the cost; provide information on best locations for a potential biomass site in each county; evaluate the economic and environmental impacts of biomass use; and provide an overview of biomass energy technologies, feedstock requirements, and the economic potential to convert biomass to electricity or ethanol.

Data Name: Assessment of Moderate- and High-Temperature Geothermal Resources of the United States

Abstract/Comments/Notes: Broad assessment of the potential of enhanced geothermal systems (EGS) within the entire United States.  The study indicates a very broad geothermal EGS resource exists.

Data Name: Estimated Temperature at 3, 4, 5, 6, and 10 Kilometer Depths
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Temperature at specific depths, with and without sedimentary basin thickness contours at 1500 m intervals
Map based on terrestrial heat flow as the primary determination for the Earth's crustal/lithospheric thermal conditions.
Surface heat flow maps and databases

Data Name: Assessment of Low Temperature Geothermal Resources of the United States
Assessment of Geothermal Resource of the United States - 1978 (circ. 790)
Regional Geothermal Database of the U.S.
Units: Many fields including location; depth (m); surface, maximum, minimum and bottom hole temperature (deg. C)
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Database of primarily regional or background wells that determine the heat flow for the United States; temperature gradients and conductivity are used to generate heat flow measurements; some wells close together have been averaged; wells within geothermal anomalies are located, but not utilized in the regional analysis.

Spatial Coverage: Western U.S. (WA, OR, ID, MT, CO, NM, AZ, UT, NV, CA)
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Inventory of the nation's low- and moderate-temperature geothermal resources for the ten western states.
Central repository for geothermal data and reports, with link to distributed data sources.

Units: Many fields including location; depth (m); surface, maximum, minimum and bottom hole temperature (deg. C)
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Database of over 5000 wells in primarily high temperature geothermal areas from the Rockies to the Pacific Ocean; all wells within a geothermal area are located where available;  the majority of the data are from company documents, well logs and publications.  Many of the wells were not previously accessible to the public

Spatial Coverage: Western Unityed States (AK, HI, WA, OR, ID, MT, WY, CO, NM, AZ, UT, NV, CA)
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Identifies broad regions of known or potential geothermal resource

Units: Many fields including location; depth (m); surface, maximum, minimum and bottom hole temperature (deg. C)
Abstract/Comments/Notes: This assessment updates prior data for near-term development of known hydrothermal resources, showing about 5.6 GW of new power by 2015 at costs less than 8 cents per kWh and an additional 13 GW projected for development within 20 years or sooner at energy costs less than 20 cents/kWh

Data Name: WGA CDEAC Geothermal Task Force Report
Spatial Coverage: WA, OR, ID, CO, NM, AZ, UT, NV, CA, AK and HI
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Estimates of near term future (2015) installed capacity of CSP and distributed solar (PV and solar thermal) by state for WGA member states.  Includes supply curves of relative resource cost.  Note, individual task force report is no longer available online.

Data Name: Geothermal Resources of the Eastern United States

Abstract/Comments/Notes: Regions favorable for the discovery at shallow depth (less than 1000m) of thermal water of sufficient temperature for direct-heat applications. It is probable that only small areas of this region are truly underlain by such thermal water; the region represents that part of the state that deserves exploration for thermal areas. The region is defined on the basis of various geothermal and tectonic phenomena such as locations of thermal wells and springs, above-normal heat flow, youthful volcanism, mineralization, and seismicity.

Areas favorable for discovery and development of low-temperature (lower than 100å¡C) geothermal resources. They are defined on the basis of thermal springs, thermal wells, and ground-water, geologic and geophysical surveys. These gray areas are modified, in the light of later information, from those shown in the U.S. Geological Survey Circular 790 (Muffler, 1979). Existing knowledge does not in general permit the inference that thermal waters may be found everywhere within the depicted areas, nor do the boundaries represent certain knowledge of the areal extent of the geothermal resources. The boundaries are subject to change as new information is obtained.

Regions favorable for the discovery at shallow depth (less than 1000m) of thermal water of sufficient temperature for direct heat applications. It is probable that only small areas of this region are truly underlain by such thermal water; the region represents that part of the state that deserves exploration for thermal areas. The region is defined on the basis of various geothermal and tectonic phenomena at such as locations of thermal wells and springs, above-normal heat flow, youthful volcanism, mineralization, and seismicity

This coverage shows areas of significant lateral extent favorable for discovery and development of local sources of low-temperature (<90å¡C) water. Areas are defined on the basis of thermal springs, wells and geohydrologic settings generally favorable for recovery of thermal water. Existing knowledge does not in general permit the inference that thermal water may be found everywhere within the depicted areas, nor do the boundaries represent certain knowledge of the areal extent of the geothermal systems

The resource is hot water co-produced with oil and gas as an enhanced geothermal system.  The water is suitable for electricity production and/or for direct thermal uses prior to re-injection.  At temperatures up to 400å¼F, it is estimated that up to 5300 MW of generation capacity could be achieved.

Regions locations where geothermal resources may exist, but evidence suggests that the probability of encountering a geothermal resource having a temperature greater than 200å¡C within 3 kilometers of the surface is 50% or less. The boundaries for these areas were drawn on the basis of geophysical and geochemical evidence and on the basis of the inferred structure and thermal resources of the individual volcanoes on each island. It is unlikely that geothermal resources will be found everywhere within the gray areas; however, the boundaries are believed to encompass all probable geothermal areas within the State of Hawaii.

Regions of significant lateral extent favorable for discovery and development of local sources of low-temperature (<90å¡C) water. Areas are defined on the basis of thermal springs, wells, and geohydrological settings generally favorable for recovery of thermal water. Existing knowledge does not in general permit the inference that thermal water may be found everywhere within the depicted areas, nor do the boundaries represent certain knowledge of the areal extent of the geothermal systems.

This coverage shows areas which, because of their geologic history and similarity to areas with know thermal systems, are expected to contain geothermal resources suitable for direct heat applications, in addition to the depicted wells and springs. The primary exploration targets are valley fill sedimentary units (less than 1000 meters in depth) receiving water from deeper basement sources. North of Garrison the area is significantly expanded to maintain private data confidentiality. East of the 109th meridian: Areas without thermal springs or shallow thermal wells, but which contains the Madison Group and deeper aquifers with water temperatures of 60å¡C (140å¡F) or greater (modified from U.S. Geological Survey Open-File Report 81-629). In much of the area wells must be deeper than 2000 meters. Holes of opportunity may be economically viable; however, corrosiveness or salinity of the water and/or limited well yield caused by low aquifer permeability or cementing of casing may impede utilization of this resource.

Regions favorable for the discovery of thermal water at shallow depth (<1000m) of sufficient temperature for direct heat applications. It is probable that only small areas of this region are underlain by such thermal water; the region represents that part of the state that deserves further exploration. Local sources of thermal water may be discovered in areas of Nevada not covered by light or dark gray. Existing data do not document the presence or lack of usable thermal water at shallow depths.

Data Name: New Geothermal Site Identification and Qualification (Geothermal)

Abstract/Comments/Notes: This coverage shows areas most favorable for discovery and development of low-temperature (<90å¡C) geothermal resources, defined on the basis of thermal springs, thermal wells, and geohydrologic settings. Areas are modified from those defined in U.S. Geological Survey Circular 790. See Sammel, E.A., 1979, Occurrence of low-temperature geothermal waters in the United States. Additional parts of the Rio Grande rift and other areas which may also be suitable for geothermal discovery but for which data are too sparse or not sufficiently diagnostic to justify inclusion in the darker gray area. Note. Existing knowledge does not in general permit the inference that thermal waters may be found everywhere within the depicted areas, nor do the boundaries represent certain knowledge of the areal extent of the geothermal systems.  The areas digitized by the INEEL from the 1980 New Mexico map were modified by James C. Witcher prior to finalizing the INEEL map.

Regions favorable for the discovery at shallow depth (less than 1,000m) of thermal water of sufficient temperature for direct heat applications. It is probable that only small areas of this region are truly underlain by such thermal water; the region represents that part of the state that deserves exploration for thermal areas. The region is defined on the basis of various geothermal, volcanic, and tectonic phenomena such as thermal wells and springs, above-normal heat flow, youthful volcanism, mineralization, seismicity, and anomalous concentrations of faults and lineaments.

Data Name: Texas Geothermal Assessment for the I35 Corridor East
Units: Temperature (deg F), depth (feet) and heat flow (mW/m2)
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Geothermal potential for Texas focused east of Interstate 35 utilizing improved subsurface temperature information.

Area of significant lateral extent favorable for discovery and development of local sources of low-temperature (<90å¡C) water. Areas are defined on the basis of thermal springs, wells, and geohydrologic settings generally favorable for recovery of thermal water. Existing knowledge does not in general permit the inference that thermal water may be found everywhere within the depicted areas, nor do the boundaries represent certain knowledge of the areal extent of the geothermal systems.

Regions favorable for exploration for, and development of, thermal water of sufficient temperature (20å¡C and higher) for direct heat applications. In the Cascade Range physiographic province low-temperature to high-temperature resources are indicated by stratovolcanoes and basaltic volcanic fields less that one million years told, geologically young silicic (andesitic and dacitic) volcanic centers, and hot springs and fumaroles. The Cascades geothermal systems have the best potential for high-temperature development in Washington. In southeastern Washington (generally the Columbia Basin physiographic province) light gray area includes wells with bottom-hole temperatures of 20å¡C and higher, and gradients higher than 45å¡C/km.

This coverage shows areas known or inferred to be underlain by aquifers containing thermal waters with temperatures higher than 50å¡C. See map explanation for discussion of methodology used to define these areas. Over much of the light gray areas, depth to 50å¡C thermal water is greater than 1500m.

Data Name: Feasibility Assessment of the Water Energy Resources of the United States for New Low Power and Small Hydro Classes of Hydroelectric Plants
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Resource sites identified by the 2004 hydropower study (item 51 of the inventory) were further evaluated to determine feasibility of development given site accessibility, proximity to load centers or transmission lines, and land use or environmental sensitivity.

Data Name: Water Energy Resources of the United States with Emphasis on Low Head/Low Power Resources
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Assessment of the water energy resources in the United States using digital elevation models and GIS tools.  The study focused, but was not limited to, low head (<30 ft) low power (<1 MW) resources.

Abstract/Comments/Notes: Assessment of undeveloped hydropower capacity in the United States.

Source: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Archive
Period of Record (published or applicabl: 1990-1998, with some observations before and after
Units: Current speed (cm/sec), direction and temperature; sea surface height; sea surface temperature
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Multiple measured and remote sensing datasets collected here with relevance for ocean energy resource assessment activities

Data Name: Ocean Current Energy Potential on the U.S. Outer Continental Shelf
Units: Ocean current relative temperature, flow, and direction
Temperature differential between surface and deep water (deg. C)

Abstract/Comments/Notes: Version 4.1 data are available through June of 2003 at daily, 8-day and monthly averages and 9km, 18km, and 54km resolutions. Data gaps occur primarily due to cloud cover because of the inability of the infrared sensor to detect ocean temperatures in these conditions. Quality flag information is available that allows the user to apply various levels of cloud masking. Current plans include extending this data at a near-real rate. Error estimates for this dataset range from 0.3 degrees Celsius to 0.5 degrees Celsius.

Source: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/ National Climatic Data Center
Period of Record (published or applicabl: One year representative of data period 1952 - 1976
Abstract/Comments/Notes: A TMY data set provides a single year of hourly data for solar radiation and other meteorological elements that permit performance comparisons of system types and configurations for one or more locations. A TMY is not necessarily a good indicator of conditions over the next year, or even the next 5 years. Rather, it represents conditions judged to be typical over a long period of time, such as 30 years. Because they represent typical rather than extreme conditions, they are not suited for designing systems and their components to meet the worst-case weather conditions that could occur at a location.  The first TMY dataset was based on extracts of the SOLMET/ERSATZ modeled estimates.

Period of Record (published or applicabl: One year representative of data period 1961 - 1990
Stated Accuracy: GHI: +/- 0.06 kWh/m2/day; DNI: +/- 0.16 kWh/m2/day; Lat = Tilt: +/- 0.09 kWh/m2/day
Abstract/Comments/Notes: A TMY data set provides a single year of hourly data for solar radiation and other meteorological elements that permit performance comparisons of system types and configurations for one or more locations. A TMY is not necessarily a good indicator of conditions over the next year, or even the next 5 years. Rather, it represents conditions judged to be typical over a long period of time, such as 30 years. Because they represent typical rather than extreme conditions, they are not suited for designing systems and their components to meet the worst-case weather conditions that could occur at a location.  The TMY2 dataset were based on the first National Solar Radiation Database, representing a period of record from 1961-1990.

Data Name: Daily Surface Weather and Climatalogical Summaries (DAYMET)
Source: University of Montana/ Numerical Terradynamic Simulation Group

Spatial Scale or Resolution: Interpolated from 8,055 meteorological stations to any point
Stated Accuracy: Interpolation of GHI ‰ÛÒ MBE = 0 W/m2; RSME = 15 W/m2; for yearly mean GHI ‰ÛÒ 17 W/m2 (10%)

Source: German Aerospace Center (DLR)/ Institute of Atmospheric Physics

Period of Record (published or applicabl: Varies from 5 to 25 yrs ago to the present
Abstract/Comments/Notes: The Solar Data Warehouse accesses climate data from over 30 different measurement networks across the United States providing hourly and daily data from over 3,000 stations.  Measurements from these networks are converted to a uniform format and combined into a consistent dataset.

Stated Accuracy: 15 W/m2 for broadband solar measure-ments and 110 W/m2 for thermal infrared measure-ments

Data Name: WGA CDEAC Solar Task Force Report
Spatial Coverage: WA, OR, ID, MT, WY, CO, NM, AZ, UT, NV, CA, TX, ND, SD, NE, KS
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Estimates of near term future (2015) installed capacity by state for WGA member states.  Includes supply curves of relative resource cost.

Spatial Coverage: FL, GA, MS, NC, SC, WV
Stated Accuracy: Varies with measured parameter and site (+/-5% to +/-15%)
Abstract/Comments/Notes: The DOE/NREL Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) Solar Measurement Network filled a geographic void in the southeastern U.S.  Due to the elimination of program funding, only two of these stations (NC & WV) continue operation as part of the CONFRRM network.

Source: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/ Earth Systems Research Laboratory
Spatial Coverage: CA, FL, ND, NM, TN, UT, WA, WI, VA
Stated Accuracy: Varies with measured parameter and site (+/-5% to +/-15%)
Abstract/Comments/Notes: The NOAA Integrated Surface Irradiance Study (ISIS) network was operated by the Global Monitoring Division (GMD).

Source: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/ Earth Systems Research Laboratory
Spatial Coverage: CO, IL, MS, MT, NV, PA, SD
Stated Accuracy: Varies with measured parameter and site (+/-5% to +/-15%)
Abstract/Comments/Notes: The NOAA Surface Radiation (SURFRAD) network is operated by the Global Monitoring Division (GMD).

Spatial Coverage: ID, MT, OR, UT, WA, WY
Stated Accuracy: Varies with measured parameter and site (+/-5% to +/-15%)
Abstract/Comments/Notes: The University of Oregon operates the Solar Radiation Monitoring Laboratory (SRML) network with support from Bonneville Power Administration, Energy Trust of Oregon, Eugene Water and Electric Board, National Energy Technology Lab, National Renewable Energy Lab, and Northwest Power and Conservation Council.

Spatial Coverage: AZ, CA, CO, NV, NM and WY

Stated Accuracy: GHI å±7%, DNI å±3%, DHIå±15% + 5 W/m2

Spatial Scale or Resolution: 23 measurement stations in 143,000 sq km area
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Atmospheric Radiation Measurements (ARM) Program provides  broadband and spectral solar radiation measurements of radiative, optical, microphysicl and chemical properties; atmospheric carbon; atmospheric state at various heights; cloud, radiometric and surface properties.

Resource Type: Multiple:  Biomass, Geothermal, Hydro, Solar & Wind
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Renewable resource maps and potential for solar, wind, biomass, hydro and geothermal compiled from various sources for the state of Texas.

Stated Accuracy: Varies with measured parameter and site (+/-5% to +/-15%)
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Cooperative Network for Renewable Resource Measurements conducts long-term solar radiation and wind measurements at across the United States.
The mesoscale network was designed and implemented by scientists at the University of Oklahoma (OU) and at Oklahoma State University (OSU) to continuously measure weather events.

Stated Accuracy: Varies with measured parameter and site (+/-5% to +/-15%)
Abstract/Comments/Notes: The National Renweable Energy Laboratory's (NREL) Solar Radiation Research Lab (SRRL) has one of the longest records of continuous solar irradiance measurements in the U.S. providing data from 1981 to the present.

Source: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/ National Climatic Data Center
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Integrated Surface Hourly (ISH) database contains the official climatological surface observations available from the National Climatic Data Center (NCDC).  The database is composed of worldwide surface weather observations from about 10,000 currently active stations, collected and stored from sources such as the US Air Force‰Ûªs Automated Weather Network (AWN) and the WMO‰Ûªs Global Telecommunications System (GTS).  The database includes data originating from various ‰ÛÏcodes‰Û such as synoptic, airways, METAR (Meteorological Routine Weather Report), and SMARS (Supplementary Marine Reporting Station), as well as observations from automatic weather stations.  There are 28 mandatory data fields, including wind direction, wind speed, total sky cover, cloud cover fields, temperature, and pressure.

Source: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration/ National Climatic Data Center

Data Name: Western Wind and Solar Integration Study
Spatial Coverage: Western Interconnect of the Continental United States
Units: Wind farm output at 100 m height
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Modeled using the WRF mesoscale model.

Data Name: An Assessment of the Available Windy Land Area and Wind Energy Potential in the Contiguous United States
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Estimate of developable windy land areas in the 48 contiguous states developed by the Pacific Northwest Natlonal Laboratory (PNNL).
Average wind speed and power density (annual and seasonal) derived from 2-minute source data

Data Name: The Spatial and Temporal Distribution of U.S. Winds and Windpower at 80 m Derived from Measurements
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Corrections to the paper: http://www.stanford.edu/group/efmh/winds/2004JD005099.pdf

Source: Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and National Renewable Energy Laboratory
Spatial Scale or Resolution: Generally 1/4 degree latitude by 1/3 degree longitude
Units: Wind Power Class at 50 m height

Data Name: US and State 80 m Wind Resource Maps and Potential
Source: National Renewable Energy Laboratory and AWS Truepower
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Wind potential calculated by NREL using commercial data licensed from AWS Truepower representing annual gross capacity factor at 80m and 100m height above ground.  Accompanying wind resource maps depict wind speed at 80m and 100m height above ground, but with a spatial resolution of 2.5 km.

Data Name: Assessment of Offshore Wind Energy Resources for the United States
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Wind resource potential based on wind speed at 90 m height above water surface.
Time series, climate variability analysis, site resource assessment

Stated Accuracy: Bias: -0.15 m/s relative to NCEP ADP; RMSE is 0.86 m/2
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Time series, climate variability analysis, site resource assessment
The 2 km resolution map information is free, and they also offer a 200 m spatial resolution commercial dataset.

Data Name: Eastern Wind Integration and Transmission Study
Spatial Coverage: Eastern Interconnect of the Continental United States
Units: Wind farm output at 80m and 100m height
Abstract/Comments/Notes: Modeled using the MASS mesoscale model for 1,326 aggregated wind farm points.  Minimum aggregation is 5 km2; maximum is 160 km2.
